members.name: Alexander Zhang
members.bio: Growing up, I was inspired by the likes of Neil DeGrasse Tyson, Bill Nye, Carl Sagan through their science outreach and fell in love with the natural sciences to become a science communicator myself. At the age of 4 I established my own paleontology Q&A platform and as I got older, I explored evolutionary biology and the exploration of the origin of life led me to the origin of the universe in astronomy and astrophysics. As you can see, I have been around the block in terms of the sciences and have developed my own philosophies to approach science communication. As Carl Sagan once said, “Science is more than a body of knowledge. It is a way of thinking; a way of skeptically interrogating the universe with a fine understanding of human fallibility”. With Students for Science, I hope to not only teach scientific content but to impart the mindset of scientific inquiry and problem solving that will be the key to many of the contemporary issues that we face today!

members.name: David Yeung
members.bio: From an early age, science and medicine were always topics of interest that would have me on the edge of my seat, trying to grasp opportunities to learn more about how life and the world around us works. As Oprah once famously said, “Education is the key to unlocking the world, a passport to freedom.” Her words have definitely rang true for me. By educating myself about science, I was able to explain a myriad of phenomena that I could not comprehend as a child and it opened my eyes to the limitless possibilities and unbounded nature of life itself. Now all grown up, I have the golden opportunity to impact the lives of more children like myself back then, and I strive to spread my passion and curiosity for science to those in our communities. I want to be able to look back at my journey with Students for Science with rose-tinted glasses and be grateful to have helped ink so many stamps into the passports of education and freedom of those around me.

members.name: Silvia Peng
members.bio: Hi I am Silvia and I like science and I think it's important for other people to learn science.

members.name: Herbert Chan
members.bio: As a child, I’ve always been interested in how the things around us work. From visits to the zoo or just watching experiments online, the opportunity to see such cool things has sparked my curiosity for science. However, I realised that I take these experiences for granted, as there are many children who are less fortunate than I am, leaving their thirst for knowledge to disappear. With Students for Science, I hope that the lessons and services we provide are able to spark their interest for sciences, and rekindle their passion for learning!

members.name: Jacky
members.bio: Just like hundreds of years ago, when The Enlightenment Resulted in an unstoppable gush of science, which stood as beacon, guiding the people out of ignorance, science has always opened the window for us to peek into the truth and core of the world with its beauty, which fascinates me always. Similar to the philosophers, we stretch out to nature and its principles by asking endless questions caused by our curiosity. Before coming across this project, my process of exploration is motivated by the pleasure of discovering new things. But now I suddenly realize that everyone has the right to be an explorer, with the seed of curiosity in their hearts, waiting for the right temperature, air and water only. For those who lack this right environmental condition , all they need is a bit of help from others and sunlight shall penetrate through the clouds. So I wish to do my part and reach out for those who are in needed. As what J.K.Rowling wrote in Harry Potter “We are as strong as we are united”. Let us do this together!

members.name: Alan Au
members.bio: Hi, my name is Alan Au, and I am the Co-head of Technology at Students for Science, and my responsibilities cover everything related to tech, including the making of this website. I like watching movies, gaming, and coding, as well as playing the oboe and the drums. I've been coding for one and a half year now, and web development for around a year. I'm proficient in both the frontend and the backend of web development.

members.name: Alvin Ng
members.bio: Hello everyone! My name is Alvin Ng, and I am the co-head of technology at Students for Science. Web development and music are both big parts of my life, which is why I often spend my free time coding and designing websites or playing the violin. I am particularly passionate about front-end web development, and I hope I will be able to contribute to and promote this project through my passion for coding and web design.

members.name: Jonathan Wu
members.bio: My passion for science arose from an early age. When I was studying in the Singapore local school system, my family subscribed to the magazine “Young Scientist”. Every month, we would receive colorfully illustrated magazines covering scientific topics ranging from marine biology to astrophysics. Reading these magazines cultivated my interest towards science to where it is today. Because of this, I believe that all children should have the opportunity to develop a passion for science, and I hope that Students for Science can help provide that.

members.name: Yuzen Wong
members.bio: Growing up, I always loved to discover and learn new things. I would constantly bombard my parents with questions about how things around me worked, or why things even happen. For example, I would ask questions like why is the sky blue? What makes a car move? Or why is grandpa starting to forget things? Luckily, being a child who comes from a privileged family, I had the resources to expand my knowledge in science and have all my questions answered. However, as I grew older, I realised that many children in Hong Kong are not as fortunate as I am. Therefore, through Students for Science, I hope to give the underprivileged children of Hong Kong the opportunity to learn science to better understand the world around them and have all their questions answered too.
